Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Robust Protocol Stack for Diverse Wireless Edge Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growth and value of the Internet today are fueled by a variety of wireless edge networks including WiFi access points in homes and public places, wireless local area networks (WLANs) in workplaces, cellular data services such as 3G, multi-hop wireless mesh networks, wireless sensor networks, mobile ad hoc networks (MANETs), and delay-tolerant networks (DTNs). This diversity poses fundamental challenges to traditional network protocols that are fragile under highly fluctuating loss, delay, and topology characteristics, and completely break down in disruption-prone environments. The diversity increases management complexity?a network administrator must pick from an intimidating number of protocol options and optimizations tuned to one environment have to be re-engineered in a different environment?stifling innovation and the long-term value of interconnecting diverse wireless edge networks.

The goal of this proposal is to architect, analyze, and implement a simple network protocol stack that ensures robust performance across diverse wireless edge networks. The key insight is to incorporate uncertainty as a first-class design concern. We adopt an unusual approach: instead of trying to make protocols in otherwise well-connected environments robust to intermittent fluctuations or disruptions, we design for an extreme point in the design space?an always-partitioned network or a DTN?and work back from those insights to ensure robust performance of protocols even in well-connected mesh networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Career project started with the goal of dependable mobile networking that "just works" in any kind of a network environment. Traditionally, computer networking is done in silos: we have very different network protocols for Internet-like networks, multi-hop WiFi networks, mobile ad-hoc networks such as those formed by moving vehicles or people in dense urban areas, and disruption-tolerant networks (DTNs) that are appropriate for rarely-connected networks such as  animal monitoring in the wild or interplanetary networks. As a consequence, networking that works in one type of environment breaks down in another.

In this project, we developed dependable networking protocols that simply work and work well no matter what type of enviroment it is. The key idea that the research leveraged was to observe that traditional protocols do not incorporate "uncertainty" or unpredictable changes in the network environment as a first-class concern, viewing them more as the exception than the norm. We developed a suite of routing, transport, link-layer, and application-layer protocols (referred to in combination as a "network protocol stack") that ensure robust performance in diverse mobile network environments.

This project also resulted in education efforts that included integrating research into course curriculum and the development of two new or significantly revamped courses: one of distributed systems and another on a software-defined networking lab.

The broader impact of this project includes some of the core ideas forming the foundational vision and technology of the MobilityFirst Future Internet Architecture NSF project. Part of the technology developed as part of these two grants has been made available to the general public in the form of a hazardous weather warning IOS app, CASA Alerts, on the Apple AppStore.
